channel.title: Applied Epidemiology I Stata lab | Enoch Yi-Tung Chen

item.title: Data management
item.description:
Learning outcomes

In this section, you will learn how to make

  • good folder structure for your project
  • good documentation
  • Readme.txt
  • habits on coding.

Learning data management can help you

  • ensure the analysis is reproducible
  • work coherently and efficiently with yourself
  • ensure the project can be understood by others (supervisors, collaborators, and future readers)
  • create a good work flow
  • enhance accuracy of work.

Video lecture (recorded in 2020)

Course notes

Slides can be downloaded below:

  • data_man_lec2021
  • data_man_video2020

Excercise

  • Instructions: exercise1_20210128
  • Solutions: make_analysis_data_upload.do

Templates for files

(from the Data Management Group, Department of Medical Epidemiology and Biostatistics)

  • Template_analysis_plan.doc
  • Template_codebook.doc
  • Template_Stata_program_header.do
  • Template_readme.txt
  • Template_logbook.docx

Suggested readings

  • The Department of Medical Epidemiology and Biostatistics, Karolinska Institutet. MEB Guidelines for Documentation and Archiving Version 6. 2018

item.title: Data Clearance
item.description:
Learning outcomes

In this section, you will learn how to

  • set up working directory
  • import and save data
  • manage datasets
  • get to know the data
  • manage variables

Video lecture

Course notes

Slides can be downloaded below:

  • data_clearance_lec2021.pdf
  • data_clearance_video2020.pdf

Stata syntax in the slides

Stata codes be downloaded data_clearance_lec2021.do.

Excercise

  • Instructions: exercise2_20210201
  • Solutions: exercise2_upload.do

item.title: Summary statistics, tables and interpreting results
item.description:
Learning outcomes

In this section, you will learn how to

  • describe summary statistics
    • measures of central tendency
    • measures of dispersion
  • make tables
    • based on basic principles
    • one-way and two by two tables
  • use Stata tool for Epidemiology
  • recapture basic epidemiology terms, including
    • rate, proportion
    • risk, risk difference, risk ratio
    • odds, odds ratio
  • interpret results of ratios
  • calculate ratios using Stata

Video lecture

Course notes

Slides can be downloaded below:

  • sumstat_lec2021.pdf
  • tab_results_lec2021.pdf
  • sumstat_tab_results_video2020.pdf.

Stata syntax in the slides

  • sumstat_lec2021.do
  • tab_results_lec2021.do.

Excercise

  • Instructions: exercise3_20210204
  • Solutions: exercise3_upload.do, exercise3_dumtab

Suggested readings

  1. Sterne JAC, White IR, Carlin JB, Spratt M, Royston P, Kenward MG, Wood AM, Carpenter JR. Multiple imputation for missing data in epidemiological and clinical research: potential and pitfalls. BMJ 2009;338:b2393–b2393.

  2. Leopold s et al, Editorial: Words Hurt – Avoiding Dehumanizing Language in Orthopaedic Research and Practice. Clin Orthop Relat Res. 2014 Sep; 472(9): 2561–2563.

  3. Enoch Chen. Avoiding Dehumanizing Language Use. (A summary of the article above.) https://enochytchen.com/post/avoid_dehumanizing/

item.title: Graphs
item.description:
Learning outcomes

In this section, you will learn how to

  • make graph based on basic principles
  • choose what graph to generate
  • use Stata to create histograms, bar charts, box plots, scatter plots, and line graphs
  • customise graphs
  • export graphs

Video lecture

Course notes

Slides can be downloaded

  • graphs_lec2021.pdf
  • graphs_video2020.pdf

Stata syntax in the slides

Stata codes be downloaded below

  • graphs_lec2021.do

Excercise

  • Instructions: exercise4_20210208.pdf
  • Solutions: exercise4_upload.do
